topic.name: Computational Thinking
topic.description: 13-year academic progression (K-12) for Computational Thinking in Computing & Digital Technologies

objectives.objective_text: Identify a bug in a simple sequence.
Identify the main parts of a story (beginning, middle, end).
Identify the main idea of a picture.
Identify irrelevant details in a problem.
Name 'First, Next, Last'.
Identify the parts of a toy (wheels, body).
Identify pushing a button makes a sound.
Name 'Clicking'.
Identify a trigger.
Identify the Start and End shapes.
Identify repeating shapes (Circle, Square, Circle...).
Identify similarities between two different games.
Identify On and Off.
Name 'Asleep' and 'Awake'.
Identify the current state of a game.
Recall that a map shows important things, not everything.
Recall that steps must be in order.
Recall the order of getting dressed.
List the ingredients needed for a sandwich.
Recall that the game waits for me.
Observe cause and effect.
Recall that a stop sign means stop.
Recall that days of the week repeat.
Recall that a traffic light changes colors.
Observe a toy that changes modes.
Follow a simple map.
Predict the next number in a simple sequence.
Draw a stick figure to represent a person.
Ignore background noise to listen to a friend.
Summarize the key features of an object (e.g., a car has wheels).
Explain why we don't need to know how the engine works to drive.
Explain how models simplify reality.
Defend the trade-off between detail and efficiency.
Follow directions to find a hidden toy.
Give instructions to a friend to draw a shape.
Summarize a recipe as an algorithm.
Explain why computers need exact instructions.
Write a list of steps to tie a shoe.
Explain the need for precision in algorithms.
Defend the logic of a solution path.
Break a daily task (like brushing teeth) into small steps.
Summarize the steps to solve a math word problem.
Explain how to break a big project into smaller jobs.
Decompose a game into rules, players, and goals.
Explain how solving small parts solves the whole.
Defend the efficiency of divide-and-conquer strategies.
Summarize 'When [event] happens, do [action]'.
Explain that the computer listens for clicks.
Explain asynchronous events (intro).
Defend the paradigm shift from procedural to event-driven.
Draw arrows to show which way to go.
Use pictures to show steps.
Summarize what a diamond shape means (Decision/Question).
Explain Pseudocode (coding in plain English).
Draw a flowchart for waking up.
Explain the flow of control.
Defend the use of planning tools before coding.
Sort items by color or size.
Summarize the rule for a number pattern.
Explain how knowing a pattern helps solve a puzzle.
Group animals by common features.
Explain how identifying patterns reduces work.
Defend the use of heuristics in problem solving.
Summarize different 'States' (Happy, Sad, Angry).
Explain what causes a change (Trigger).
Draw a diagram of a light switch.
Explain why a machine can't be in two states at once.
Defend the use of state machines for robust code.
Analyze the concept of a 'Black Box' (input/output without seeing inside).
Interpret a transit map as an abstraction of geography.
Connect variables to generalizing specific values.
Analyze an algorithm for efficiency.
Interpret a set of rules for a card game.
Connect inputs to outputs via a process.
Analyze a complex problem to identify sub-problems.
Interpret a top-down design approach.
Connect decomposition to modular programming.
Analyze the event loop concept.
Interpret event handlers.
Connect user interaction to code execution.
Analyze a flowchart with loops.
Interpret pseudocode into a real programming language.
Connect standard symbols (process, input/output) to logic.
Analyze data to find trends.
Interpret reusable code segments.
Connect patterns in nature (fractals) to algorithms.
Analyze a Finite State Machine (FSM) diagram.
Interpret transitions based on inputs.
Connect state logic to vending machines.
Evaluate the level of abstraction needed for a simulation.
Evaluate the correctness of an algorithm (tracing).
Evaluate the independence of decomposed modules.
Evaluate the responsiveness of event handling.
Evaluate a flowchart for infinite loops.
Evaluate pattern matching algorithms (Regex).
Evaluate the completeness of transition conditions.
Create a symbol to represent a complex idea.
Construct an abstract data type (ADT).
Synthesize object-oriented classes as abstractions.
Construct a novel algorithm to solve a unique problem.
Synthesize algorithmic complexity (Big O) considerations.
Construct a project breakdown structure for a software application.
Synthesize component integration after decomposition.
Create a script that starts when a key is pressed.
Construct an event-driven application (GUI).
Synthesize listeners and callbacks.
Construct detailed pseudocode for a complex function.
Synthesize logic design with implementation.
Construct a general solution based on specific cases.
Synthesize machine learning concepts (identifying patterns in data).
Construct a state diagram for a turnstile or character AI.
Synthesize Moore and Mealy machines (introductory).
